section.name: Welcome to Mod4j
section.p: Mod4j is a project that focuses on Model Driven Software Development. It's goal is to improve the productivity of Java software development by using Domain Specific Languages.

li.a: What are the features of Mod4j?

ol.li: Make sure you've installed Java JDK version 5 (1.5.0_15 or higher). You can download one from the Sun download site .

Download and install Eclipse with modeling plug-ins. To minimize time spending on version en dependency conflicts we already have a version waiting for you to download. This version based on Eclipse Europa 3.3.2, OAW 4.3, EMF 2.3.1 and has some convenient plug-ins (like Q4E and Subclipse). You can download a Windows or Linux archive from our project share here

Make sure you start Eclipse with de right options, e.g on a linux system: /path-to-eclipse-mod4j/Eclipse-europa/eclipse -vm /path-to-jdk1.5.0_15/jre/bin/java -vmargs -Xms512m -Xmx512m -XX:PermSize=512m -XX:MaxPermSize=512m

Make sure the text file encoding in Eclipse is set to 'UTF-8'. You can verify and set this in the field 'Text file encoding' by navigating to 'Window -> Preferences... -> General -> Workspace'. For Linux users UTF-8 is usually the platform encoding, and no change will be necessary.
Install the Mod4j DSL Eclipse plugins as described in the next section.

subsection.name: Installing the Mod4j DSL Eclipse plugins
subsection.p:
The Mod4j DSL Eclipse plugins can be installed from the Mod4j update site:
Mod4j update site: https://repo.smart-java.nl/mod4j/updatesite

ol.li: In Eclipse navigate to: Help, Software Updates, Find and Install...
Choose the option "Search for new features to install" and click on "Next".
To create a new remote site for Mod4j, click on "New Remote Site".
Enter the URL: https://repo.smart-java.nl/mod4j/updatesite and click on "OK"
After clicking on "Finish" you will be prompted for your SMART-Java username and password
Next you can select the Mod4j features of your choice. Complete the wizard to install the chosen features.

subsection.name: Modelling
subsection.p: If you've completed the installation steps above, you're ready for moddeling...
You can use the following DSL's in your project:

ol.li:
First of all you need to create a new Eclipse project for each DSL you're going to use.
For instance if you want to create a BusinessDomain model, choose: File, New, Project, Xtext DSL Wizards, BusinessDomainDSL project .

In the new project create a directory structure like in our RecordShop example project:
src/main/model/model.busmod
src/main/workflow/businessGenerator.oaw
src/main/workflow/workflow.properties

subsection.name: Generating source code
subsection.p: If you've completed your model(s) in the previous section, you're ready for generating source code out of the models.

ol.li: The previous step generated two modules into the RecordShop-Application folder. See: ../RecordShop-Application/RecordShop-domain and ../RecordShop-Application/RecordShop-data
